DOCNAME: CASE OF KOKY AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Effective investigation) (Procedural aspect);Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed (Article 41 - Pecuniary damage);Non-pecuniary damage - award (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage)
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: CARDINAL . The following incidents occurred on DATE . The detailed accounts of events by the parties and those involved are at variance at times . In this section , therefore , the incidents are described only briefly . Differing details , if any , are pointed out in the subsequent sections .

CARDINAL . In TIME of DATE , at TIME , an argument started in a bar in the village of Gánovce - Filice , when a non - Romani waitress , PERSON , refused to serve a drink to a person of GPE ethnic origin , GPE

CARDINAL . The argument developed with the tipping of a drink over GPE , in response to which he slapped or attempted to slap PERSON in the face , accidentally knocking glasses over , which fell and broke .

CARDINAL . Subsequently GPE telephoned CARDINAL of her CARDINAL sons , PERSON , who came to the bar soon afterwards . After he had left , another of her sons , PERSON , who was the owner of the bar , came to the bar and remained there , assisting PERSON in serving customers , until closing time . Around that time , the girlfriend of GPE , ORG , also came to the bar and then accompanied PERSON home .

CARDINAL . TIME , at TIME , a group of CARDINAL people went into the GPE settlement in the village where the applicants lived . Some of them were wearing balaclavas and they were armed with baseball bats and iron bars .
CARDINAL . Allegedly shouting racist language , they forcibly entered houses nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE , damaging the interior and breaking the windows .

CARDINAL . On entering house no . CARDINAL , the attackers physically assaulted applicant Mr PERSON . Some of the other applicants and another person , who were also present at the house during the attack , witnessed the attack but managed to avoid it by hiding ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . Once the attackers understood that the police had been called , they made their escape . When they had gone QUANTITY from the settlement , they met applicants Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON and physically assaulted them , causing them the injuries described below . Racist language is alleged to have been used during this part of the attack too .
CARDINAL . NORP House CARDINAL was inhabited by applicant PERSON and her partner , GPE They were both at home during the attack .
CARDINAL . House CARDINAL was inhabited by applicants Mr PERSON , PERSON , Mr PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and Mr PERSON and by a certain PERSON
Apart from applicant PERSON , they were all present at the house during the incident , and so were applicants Mr PERSON and a certain PERSON
CARDINAL . When the attack took place in his house , applicant Mr PERSON sustained no physical injuries .
CARDINAL . House CARDINAL was owned and inhabited by applicant PERSON .
CARDINAL . The overall damage to the applicants’ property was estimated at the equivalent of QUANTITY ORG ) .
CARDINAL . The parties are not united over the extent of the physical injuries sustained by Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . The applicants claim that Mr PERSON suffered a skull fracture , a cut to the left side of the back of the head , a crushed left arm , a pressure injury to the left side of the back and bruises to the left knee , which required him to stay in hospital for DATE .

CARDINAL . As regards Mr PERSON , the applicants claim that he had sustained a scraped elbow and a crushed arm , which required a recovery time of DATE . In that respect the applicants relied on the decisions of CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . In contrast , the ORG submit that Mr PERSON injuries necessitated no stay in hospital , while those of Mr PERSON only required him to stay in hospital for DATE .
CARDINAL . After GPE had come home from her shift , an unknown person broke the window of her house by throwing a stone at it and also broke the windows of a car parked in her yard .
CARDINAL . It is not entirely clear what relation this attack bore to the argument at the bar and the attack at the settlement , both in terms of time and of cause .
CARDINAL . It appears that those present during the attack at ORG house included GPE , GPE , ORG , her brother : ORG , and a certain PERSON

CARDINAL . The police arrived at the GPE settlement TIME after the incident . TIME and in TIME of the following day , that is to say DATE , the police carried out inspections and interviews , as summarised below on the basis of official records .

CARDINAL . TIME house no . CARDINAL was inspected in connection with a suspected offence , which was referred to as “ damage to family house ” . Applicant Mr PERSON , who lived in the house , was present .
Broken windows were found in various parts of the house , and CARDINAL biological traces were identified ( bloodstains on a door and on a baseball bat ) and sent for further analysis .
CARDINAL . CARDINAL no . DATE was inspected in connection with a suspected offence , which was referred to as “ damage to windows and door of a house ” . GPE , whose house it was , was present .

Damage to the latch and casing of the front door were identified , as well as broken panes in CARDINAL of the windows . Inside the house , on the floor in the kitchen and a room where the windows had been broken , CARDINAL stones of CARDINAL and QUANTITY diameter were found .

CARDINAL . TIME the following day house no CARDINAL was inspected in connection with a suspected offence , which was referred to as “ damage to a window pane of a house ” . Applicant Ms Justína Lacková , whose house it was , was present .
Broken panes in CARDINAL windows were identified , and CARDINAL biological trace was sampled for further analysis .
CARDINAL . Applicant Mr Ján Koky , GPE and applicant PERSON were interviewed : the interviews started at TIME , TIME and TIME respectively .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON submitted , inter alia , that earlier that TIME a group of CARDINAL attackers had entered his house , no . CARDINAL . They had been armed with batons and had tried to hit him . He managed to fend them off and other occupants of his house had managed to hide , so the attackers had mainly been hitting the kitchen furnishings . CARDINAL of the attackers were wearing balaclavas to conceal their faces . The remaining one , whom he did not know , had no balaclava . They had not uttered a word .

CARDINAL . Z.K. described how the attackers had broken windows in his house , no . CARDINAL , had forcibly entered and had made their escape after learning that the police were on their way . According to the transcript , the interview ended at TIME then added that when they entered his house the attackers were shouting : “ NORP , we ’re going to strike you down today ” .

CARDINAL . Ms Justína Lacková submitted that she had been at home with her CARDINAL minor children during the attack and that her husband had not been there . She had witnessed the turmoil outside her house through a window . CARDINAL of her house windows had subsequently been broken , probably with sticks , because no stones or other foreign objects had been found inside . In her submission , the attackers had pounded at her entrance door but had not succeeded in getting in . PERSON assessed the damage to her house and submitted a claim for compensation to the proceedings . The interview was concluded at TIME and then reopened to pose a direct question to the applicant , in response to which she retorted that , on the part of the attackers , she had only heard indistinct shouting . The interview was finally concluded at TIME

QUANTITY . , as applicable at that time ) respectively .

It was also suspected that while at his house the attackers had tried to hit applicant Mr PERSON with baseball bats and that while making their escape from the scene of crime , they had assaulted applicants Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON by hitting them with baseball bats and kicking them , thus causing them bodily injuries on account of which , according to a preliminary estimate , they would need recovery time and would be unfit for work for DATE and DATE respectively .

CARDINAL . The injuries to the applicants Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON were also assessed in an expert medical report procured by the DPI , in which their recovery time was assessed at DATE and DATE respectively .
CARDINAL . On DATE respectively , an official note was made in the investigation file summarising the applicants’ submissions and a document was included in it outlining the investigation strategy .

On DATE at CARDINAL and TIME respectively , the DPI interviewed PERSON and GPE They described their involvement in the incident at the pub and the subsequent attack which took place at ORG house and on his car . PERSON submitted , inter alia , that she had closed the bar and had gone home at TIME P.S. submitted that the closing time of the bar was TIME and that his mother had arrived home after that time .

CARDINAL . On DATE the DPI reported to ORG on the status of the investigation . It was mentioned , inter alia , that the applicants’ legal representative had been obstructing the investigation , in that he had instructed the applicants not to accept summonses to interviews if handed to them in person , and not to take part in any interviews unless he was present . The qualification of the representative to appear on the applicants’ behalf in criminal proceedings in GPE was also called into question .

CARDINAL . In TIME , the DPI interviewed applicant Mr PERSON , GPE and GPE and applicants Mr PERSON and PERSON PERSON . These interviews started at CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL respectively .

Mr PERSON described the pub incident between GPE and GPE According to him , following the altercation PERSON had called P.S. , who had arrived within TIME , and who had warned PERSON that another son of PERSON would come round and there would be trouble . He also submitted that , TIME , CARDINAL men had caught and beaten him , that he had subsequently had to be taken to hospital by ambulance , that he had been hospitalised for DATE and that due to his injuries he was still unfit for work . In response to a direct question , Mr PERSON submitted that “ during the attack , none of the attackers uttered a word ” .
CARDINAL . T.K. and GPE submitted that on TIME of the incident they had seen PERSON with a group of CARDINAL men approaching the GPE settlement .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON described the pub incident , including the remark that P.S. had told him and others to go away because his brother would come and there would be trouble . Mr PERSON also submitted that , after he had seen his brother , applicant Mr PERSON , and his injuries , he had been convinced that DATE was responsible . He had therefore gone to ORG house , where he had had a verbal exchange with ORG and ORG However , he had gone away after the latter had produced a handgun and threatened to shoot him .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON described the pub incident , the arrival of P.S. in the pub , the departure of CARDINAL men and the assault on him by CARDINAL individuals wearing balaclavas to conceal their faces and CARDINAL without , accompanied with a cry “ Negroes , gypsies , we ’re going to kill you ” . After receiving medical care in hospital , he had gone home and had not been hospitalised .

CARDINAL . PERSON , who lived in house no . CARDINAL , gave an account of the assault at their house and settlement , submitting that it had been accompanied by shouts of “ Get out ! ” , “ [ religious expletive ] , gypsy whores , gypsy gang , get out , or else we are going to kill you all ! ” and “ Gypsy whores , DATE you are dead , you are going to get a kicking DATE ! ” .

CARDINAL . PERSON gave an account of the attack at her house , no . CARDINAL , submitting that it had been accompanied by a male voice shouting “ Gypsies , black muzzles , today you are going to get killed , get out ! ” .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON gave an account of the attack at house no . CARDINAL , where he lived , submitting that it had been accompanied by shouts of “ GPE , today you are going to be burned ” .
CARDINAL . PERSON , who was in house no . CARDINAL during the attack , gave an account of it and submitted that it had been accompanied by shouts of “ GPE , black muzzles , get out ! ”

The decision was based on the suspicion that , in the incident described above , several unidentified individuals had entered the GPE settlement shouting “ NORP , come out or we will kill you ” , while some of them had gone into houses CARDINAL and CARDINAL shouting “ NORP , come out or we will kill you ” .
CARDINAL . The decision refers to the charges of DATE and to subsequent statements from PERSON , GPE , GPE and applicants Mr PERSON , Mr PERSON , PERSON , Mr PERSON , Mr PERSON , PERSON and Mr PERSON

CARDINAL . At TIME on DATE the DPI started interviewing applicant Mr PERSON , who completed his depositions of DATE in so far as the extent of the material damage he had sustained was concerned , and added a claim for compensation to the proceedings .

DATE . Without providing any details the Government submitted that “ [ the authorities ] had requested records of incoming and outgoing communication to and from mobile phones of [ ORG ] , [ GPE ] , [ P.S. ] and [ E.N. ] ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE the DPI held an identity exercise , in the course of which the participants were to identify presumed perpetrators from photographs in albums . It produced the following results :
- applicant Mr PERSON identified CARDINAL person , with a subjectively perceived probability of PERCENT , as CARDINAL of the people who had been attacking him in his house ;

- applicant Mr PERSON recognised CARDINAL individual , who had been present at the pub during the argument , but had not been among those who had beaten him . He also identified CARDINAL individual who had been among those who had beaten him , of which he was PERCENT sure .
- applicant PERSON identified CARDINAL individual , with a subjectively perceived probability of PERCENT , as an intruder in their house and an attacker of her father ;

- applicant Mr PERSON recognised CARDINAL individuals who had been present at the pub during the argument but had not been among those who had beaten him . He also identified CARDINAL individual who had been present at the settlement during the attack but was not sure whether that individual had beaten him ; and
- applicants PERSON , PERSON and Mr PERSON did not identify anyone .

CARDINAL . NORP In what may appear to be a follow - up to the identity exercise , on DATE , the DPI requested ORG to examine buccal mucus samples of CARDINAL individuals , GPE , GPE and GPE and to compare biological material thus obtained with other biological evidence taken from the scene of crime .

CARDINAL . On DATE the DPI suspended the above - mentioned criminal investigations . The decision stated that the police had taken several investigative measures and had carried out a search with a view to establishing the identity of the perpetrators of the assault of CARDINAL DATE . Until then , however , no evidence could be established which would have made it possible to bring charges against a specific person .

CARDINAL . The decision of DATE also stated that it was established that the incident at the GPE settlement “ had been preceded by an assault on a waitress , PERSON , by a GPE , GPE , and subsequent damage to the property of the family of GPE by a hitherto unidentified GPE and so the actions of the unidentified perpetrators [ could ] not be considered or qualified as a criminal offence with a racial motive , because it [ had come ] down only to an act of retribution ” .
CARDINAL . As to the injuries sustained by applicants Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON , the decision refers to the decision of DATE and its contents ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE applicants Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON lodged an interlocutory appeal ( sťažnosť ) against the decision to suspend the investigation . Referring to the facts of the case , they submitted that the assault had been racially motivated and that it had been organised by people who were close to the family of the waitress concerned . Citing , inter alia , ORG and CARDINAL of the Convention , they sought resumption of the investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE , namely DATE , ORG ( Okresná prokuratúra ) ( “ the District Prosecutor ” ) issued a written instruction to the DPI specifying the measures to be taken and lines of inquiry to be pursued in order to establish the identity of the perpetrators and highlight the alleged racial motive .

DATE . Still on DATE , the DPI took a decision to resume the investigation . That decision contains a summary of the previous procedural developments , followed by a plain statement , without further elucidation , that “ during further investigation it [ had been ] established that a racially motivated criminal offence [ was ] implicated and therefore it [ was ] necessary to take further investigative steps and resume the investigation ... ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG filed a report with the DPI concluding that , having examined the biological material of GPE , GPE and GPE ( see paragraph DATE above ) and having compared it with the material taken from the crime scene , no link could be established .

CARDINAL . In TIME DATE , at TIME , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL respectively , the DPI commenced interviewing GPE , GPE and GPE , as well as ORG They completed their respective submissions of DATE , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE and agreed to provide buccal mucus samples for the purposes of DNA testing and comparison with the biological material taken from the crime scene .

CARDINAL . On DATE at TIME the DPI commenced interviewing PERSON , who gave an account of his arrival in the village and at the bar and also of his perception of the incident at the house of PERSON He stated that he had not been at the GPE settlement .

CARDINAL . The following day the DPI again requested ORG to analyse and compare biological material obtained from the CARDINAL sons of GPE , GPE and GPE with the material taken from the scene of crime .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the interlocutory appeal of applicants Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) inadmissible , replying on Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL § CARDINAL , CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( b ) and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the ORG , and holding that as victims of the alleged offences the appellants had no standing to challenge the decision in question .

CARDINAL . In its concluding part , which under the applicable procedural rules ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) contains information concerning available remedies , the decision provided that : “ An interlocutory appeal against this decision is not permissible . ”

CARDINAL . However , in a letter of DATE , namely CARDINAL DATE , ORG informed the applicants that she had reviewed the matter on her own authority , that on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) she had quashed the decision , and that she had instructed the DPI to carry on the investigation so as to clarify the events without leaving any doubt as to the identity and motive of the alleged perpetrators .

On CARDINAL , DATE and DATE respectively the DPI interviewed PERSON ( at TIME ) , P.P. ( at TIME ) and ORG ( before TIME ) .

CARDINAL . In addition , ORG submitted that he had not been at the GPE settlement and that he had no explanation of how he could have been identified as someone involved in the attack .

CARDINAL . J.H. had been away on a skiing trip from DATE until DATE .
CARDINAL . M.K. had been away on business in DATE in question and had only returned on DATE .

It summarised previous procedural developments and observed that , despite additional information taken from PERSON , GPE , GPE and applicants Mr PERSON , Mr PERSON , ORG , Mr PERSON , Mr PERSON , PERSON and Mr PERSON , it had not been possible to establish any evidence allowing charges to be brought against any specific person . CARDINAL . On DATE applicants Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON lodged an interlocutory appeal against the decision of DATE , requesting that the criminal proceedings be resumed with a view to establishing the relevant facts of the case .

CARDINAL . The appellants relied on Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention , CARDINAL of Protocol No . CARDINAL and DATE and DATE of the LAW and referred to the results of the identity exercise on DATE . In particular , they emphasised that , on that occasion , applicant Mr PERSON had recognised CARDINAL person ; applicant Mr PERSON had recognised ORG and submitted that the organisation of the attack had had a connection with the family of GPE ; and applicants Mr PERSON and PERSON had recognised CARDINAL person each .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG representative wrote to ORG to inform him that they had lodged an interlocutory appeal against the decision of DATE with ORG and that they suspected that the investigation had been tampered with in order to downplay the racial motive for the assault . He requested that the applicants be informed of ORG office ’s actions in the matter .

CARDINAL . The applicants have not received any answer to their letter of CARDINAL DATE , and it appears that it has not given rise to any specific action or decision . According to an official statement of ORG the letter is not a part of their case file .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the interlocutory appeal inadmissible on similar grounds to those in the decision of CARDINAL DATE , relying on Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL § CARDINAL a CARDINAL of the ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The decision contains information as to the available remedies , to the effect that : “ An interlocutory appeal against this decision is not permissible . ”

CARDINAL . Nevertheless , ORG reviewed the decision on her own initiative and , by a letter of DATE , namely DATE , informed the appellants that the DPI had taken all the actions necessary to carry out a successful prosecution .

CARDINAL . According to the letter , it was true that applicant Mr PERSON had recognised GPE , ORG and ORG , but he had submitted either that they had not beaten him or that he was not sure whether they had beaten him . Applicant Mr PERSON had recognised ORG and had submitted that it was the latter who had beaten him in his house . This submission however contradicted a previous submission by applicant Mr PERSON ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) to the effect that , of the CARDINAL attackers in his house , CARDINAL were wearing balaclavas and CARDINAL , whom he did not know , was not . It was also observed that PERSON had not recognised any of the attackers .

ORG . The letter further states that additional action had been taken with a view to identifying those responsible , such as a comparison of the traces found at the scene of the incident with buccal mucus samples from the suspects , but the available evidence did not permit the bringing of charges against any particular person .
CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE and again on DATE and DATE , the FAC interviewed CARDINAL other individuals . These interviews however produced no useful new information .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date , in response to a request of CARDINAL DATE , ORG reported to the DPI that , having examined buccal mucus samples from GPE , GPE and PERSON and compared it with the biological material taken from the scene of crime , no link could be established .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in response to a request , the DPI reported to ORG that hitherto “ no perpetrator had been identified and that tasks were continuously being carried out under an integrated investigation plan ” .
CARDINAL . No information has been made available in respect of any further investigative actions and their outcome .

CARDINAL . On DATE all CARDINAL applicants lodged a complaint with ORG under LAW . Represented by a lawyer , they contended that the events of DATE had not been sufficiently thoroughly and efficiently investigated to ensure that those responsible were identified and punished . In particular , they submitted that the authorities had failed to draw adequate conclusions from the oral evidence and from the information concerning the identity of the alleged perpetrators , as obtained from the identity exercise of DATE . In addition , the authorities should have taken and assessed further evidence , such as records of mobile telephone communications between those involved , but had not done so . The applicants also contended that the assault had not been motivated by revenge but was racially motivated , to which the authorities had failed to pay adequate attention .

CARDINAL . In the text of their complaint the applicants made reference to LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . , as amended ) , in conjunction with a principle of “ general acceptance and observance of human rights and basic freedoms for everybody ” , Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention and the ORG ’s judgment in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINALVI ) .

CARDINAL . In the standardised prescribed form containing a summary of their claim , the applicants applied for a ruling declaring a violation of their right to an effective remedy under LAW and to judicial and other legal protection under LAW by actions of the DPI in the investigation referred to above .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the complaint inadmissible on the ground that the applicants had failed to exhaust all remedies as required by section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . , as amended ) .

CARDINAL . NORP In particular , ORG held that it had been open to the applicants to ask ORG ( “ the PPS ” ) , under Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( a ) and ( c ) of the ORG , to instruct the DPI to proceed with the case . Had such a request been dismissed , the applicants could have used further remedies available to them under sections CARDINAL et seq . of LAW .
No appeal against the decision of ORG was available .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that :
“ GPE acknowledges and adheres to general rules of international law , international treaties by which it is bound , and its other international obligations . ”
CARDINAL . In so far as relevant , LAW stipulates that :
“ CARDINAL . Everyone has the right to life . [ ... ]
CARDINAL . No one shall be deprived of life .
CARDINAL . No infringement of rights according to this Article shall occur if a person has been deprived of life in connection with an action not defined as unlawful under the law . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that :
“ The home shall be inviolable . Entry without the consent of the person living there is not permitted . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW reads as follows :

“ Everyone may claim his or her right by procedures laid down by an act of parliament before an independent and impartial court of law or , in cases provided for by an act of parliament , before another organ of GPE . ”
CARDINAL . Pursuant to Article CARDINAL :

“ CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court shall decide complaints by natural or legal persons alleging a violation of their fundamental rights or freedoms ... unless the protection of such rights and freedoms falls within the jurisdiction of a different court .

CARDINAL . NORP If ORG finds a complaint justified , it shall deliver a decision stating that a person ’s rights or freedoms as set out in paragraph CARDINAL have been violated by a final decision , specific measure or other act , and shall quash such a decision , measure or act . If the violation that has been found is the result of a failure to act , ORG may order [ the authority ] which has violated the rights or freedoms to take the necessary action . At the same time it may remit the case to the authority concerned for further proceedings , order that authority to refrain from violating the fundamental rights and freedoms ... or , where appropriate , order those who have violated the rights or freedoms set out in paragraph CARDINAL to restore the situation to that existing prior to the violation .
CARDINAL . NORP In its decision on a complaint ORG may grant appropriate financial compensation to a person whose rights under paragraph CARDINAL have been violated . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL reads as follows :

“ Unless this LAW provides otherwise or it is excluded by the nature of the matter , the proceedings before the Constitutional Court shall be subject to application mutatis mutandis of the provisions of LAW and LAW . ”
CARDINAL . Under the relevant part of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) :

“ CARDINAL . A[n ] [ individual ] complaint is not admissible if the complainant has not exhausted legal remedies or other legal means , which a statute effectively provides to [ the complainant ] with a view to protecting [ the complainant ’s ] fundamental rights or freedoms , and which the complainant is entitled to use under special statute [ such as LAW and LAW ] .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court shall not declare ORG ] [ individual ] complaint inadmissible even if the condition under paragraph CARDINAL has not been fulfilled , if the complainant establishes that [ the complainant ] has not fulfilled this condition due to reasons worthy of particular consideration . ”
CARDINAL . The purpose of the ORG is defined in its LAW as follows :

“ The purpose of the [ ORG ] is to regulate actions of the agencies involved in criminal proceedings with a view to establishing properly whether criminal offences have been committed and to punishing perpetrators lawfully and justly . The proceedings must work for reinforcement of compliance with the law , for prevention and obstruction of crime , [ and ] for the education of citizens in the spirit of consistent compliance with the law and rules of civic coexistence , as well as honest fulfilment of duties towards the ORG and the society . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The fundamental principles of criminal proceedings are laid down in LAW , the relevant parts of CARDINAL of which provide :

“ CARDINAL . The prosecutor is duty bound to prosecute all criminal offences of which [ he or she ] has been apprised ; any exception is permissible only under statue or a promulgated international treaty .

CARDINAL . NORP The agencies involved in criminal proceedings shall proceed so that the facts of the matter are duly established , to the extent which is absolutely necessary for their decision . With equal care , they shall elucidate circumstances both against and in favour of the charged person and , in both respects , they shall take and examine evidence without awaiting the parties’ proposals .... ”

CARDINAL . The role of victims of crimes in criminal proceedings is defined in section ( Oddiel ) CARDINAL of chapter ( PERSON ) CARDINAL in part ( Časť ) one . The relevant part of its LAW provides as follows :

“ CARDINAL . A victim is a person upon whom a criminal offence has inflicted health damage , property damage , non - pecuniary damage or other damage or it has violated or jeopardised [ his or her ] rights or freedoms protected by law . A victim has ... the right to lodge [ in the proceedings ] [ his or her ] claim for damages ; to propose that evidence be taken , examined and completed ; to take part in the hearing , ... ; to comment on the evidence taken and examined ... ; and to make use of legal remedies to the extent defined by the ORG ...

CARDINAL . A victim who has a lawful claim against a person facing charges for compensation in respect of damage inflicted [ on the victim ] by a criminal offence , shall be entitled to propose that , in a judgment leading to conviction , the court should impose a duty on the accused to compensate for that damage . The proposal shall be made at the latest during the main court hearing before the presentation of evidence . The proposal has to be clear as to the ground and the amount of damages claimed . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW in Part CARDINAL contains rules concerning the making of and dealing with applications , the relevant part of its LAW § CARDINAL providing that :
“ An application shall be assessed according to its content , irrespective of whether it is incorrectly named . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of Chapter CARDINAL in Part CARDINAL lays down rules concerning decisions ( uznesenie ) , paragraph CARDINAL , the relevant part of which is cited below , defining the attributes , structure and content of a decision :
“ CARDINAL . A decision must contain ...
e ) information about available remedies . ”
CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL in Part CARDINAL regulates interlocutory appeals against decisions , their admissibility being defined in LAW , the relevant part of which provides :
“ CARDINAL . A remedy in respect of decisions consists of an interlocutory appeal .

CARDINAL . An interlocutory appeal shall be available against any decision of an investigator or a police authority except for a decision on the opening of a criminal prosecution ( Article CARDINAL ) . A decision by a court or by a prosecutor may be challenged by an interlocutory appeal only in those instances where the statute expressly so provides and if [ a matter ] is being decided on at first instance . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL contains locus standi for such appeals , as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Unless provided for otherwise by a statute , an interlocutory appeal may be lodged by a person who is directly affected by the [ impugned ] decision or who has prompted the decision by a request which [ the appellant ] was entitled to make by law .... ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW in Part CARDINAL regulates investigations , Article CARDINAL providing for the possibility of having an investigator ’s actions reviewed , in the following terms :

“ The person facing charges and the victim shall have the right at any time in the course of the investigation to demand that a prosecutor [ ensure ] that delays in the investigation or shortcomings on the part of the investigator be eliminated . The right to make such a demand shall not be restricted by any time - limit . This demand , which must be submitted to the prosecutor at once , must be dealt with by the prosecutor without delay . The outcome of the review must be notified to the person making the demand . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW in Part CARDINAL deals with decisions at the preliminary stage of the proceedings , the relevant part of LAW providing that :
“ CARDINAL . An investigator shall suspend criminal proceedings ...
( e ) if it has been impossible to identify evidence allowing for the prosecution of a particular person ...

CARDINAL . Prior to suspending criminal proceedings everything needs to be done which is necessary for securing a successful completion of a criminal prosecution . Should there no longer be any reason for the suspension , the criminal proceedings shall be resumed . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW in Part CARDINAL regulates the prosecutor ’s supervision of adherence to lawfulness in pre - trial proceedings , the relevant part of Article CARDINAL providing that :
“ CARDINAL . Supervision of lawfulness in pre - trial proceedings shall be carried out by the prosecutor .
CARDINAL . While carrying out this supervision , the prosecutor shall have the power :
( a ) to give binding instructions for the investigation of criminal offences ...

( c ) to take part in activities carried out by an investigator or a police authority or directly to take a particular action , to carry out the entire investigation and to take a decision on any matter whereby the provisions of [ the ORG ] normally applicable to an investigator shall apply to the prosecutor mutatis mutandis and , as a decision of an investigator , the decision by the prosecutor shall be challengeable by an interlocutory appeal . ”
CARDINAL . The Act entered into force on DATE , replacing previous legislation ( Law no . PERSON . , as amended ) . The object of the LAW is defined in its section CARDINAL , which reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . This Act determines the status and jurisdiction of ORG , the status and jurisdiction of ORG , the status of other prosecutors , organisation and administration of ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP The status of prosecutors ; their rights and obligations ; the establishment , modification and termination of [ their ] service relationship and the claims ensuing from it ; the relationships of responsibility ; disciplinary proceedings and selfgovernance of prosecutors shall be subject to a special statute . ”
CARDINAL . Petitions to the PPS are regulated by Part ( Časť ) CARDINAL of the LAW . Pursuant to the relevant part of its LAW :

“ CARDINAL . A prosecutor may examine the lawfulness of actions and decisions of bodies of public administration , prosecutors , investigators , police authorities and courts in so far as a statute so provides , including upon a petition , and is entitled to take measures to rectify established violations , provided [ such measures ] do not fall under a special statute within the exclusive jurisdiction of other bodies .

CARDINAL . A petition is understood as a written or oral demand , proposal or other submission by an individual or a legal entity , which is aimed at a prosecutor taking a measure within [ the prosecutor ’s ] jurisdiction , in particular lodging an application for proceedings to commence before a court , or submitting a remedy , joining existing proceedings , or taking other measures for rectification of a violation of the law , which fall within [ the prosecutor ’s ] jurisdiction . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant part of section CARDINAL provides that :
“ CARDINAL . A prosecutor is duty bound to process a petition within DATE of its introduction ...
CARDINAL . A prosecutor shall notify a petitioner within the period specified in subsection CARDINAL of the manner in which the petition has been resolved . [ ... ] ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL deals with repeated petitions and further repeated petitions . Its relevant part reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . A petitioner may demand a review of the lawfulness of how the petition has been resolved by means of a repeated petition , which shall be dealt with by a prosecutor at a higher level .

CARDINAL . A further repeated petition shall be dealt with by a prosecutor at a higher level only if it contains new information . A further repeated petition is understood to be a third and any further consecutive petition , in which the petitioner expresses discontent with the manner in which [ his or her ] petitions in the same matter have been resolved . ”
CARDINAL . Under the relevant part of section CARDINAL :

“ CARDINAL . In dealing with a petition , a prosecutor is duty bound to examine all circumstances decisive for the assessment of whether there has been a violation of the law ; whether the conditions are fulfilled for lodging an application for proceedings before a court to commence or for submitting a remedy ; or whether [ the prosecutor ] may join existing proceedings before a court or take other measures which [ the prosecutor ] is entitled to take under [ LAW ] . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The prosecutor assesses the petition according to its content ...

CARDINAL . NORP If the prosecutor establishes that a petition is well founded , [ he or she ] shall take measures for rectification of the violation of law pursuant to [ LAW ] or a special statute . ”

CARDINAL . NORP In a decision of DATE ( in case no . III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ORG declared inadmissible a submission , in which an individual had complained that criminal proceedings against him had been too lengthy and that they , as well as a warrant for his arrest , had been unjustified .

In rejecting the claim , ORG held that , in respect of the criminal proceedings as such , it was for the applicant first to seek redress from the investigator or the supervising prosecutor by the means available under the ORG and , as the case might be , also from a higher level of the ORG by means available under LAW . As to the arrest warrant , it was for the applicant to assert his rights before the ordinary courts .

CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE ( in case no . I. ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ORG declared inadmissible a complaint under LAW , in which an individual had contested the way the ORG had handled his complaint concerning interference with his correspondence by prison authorities .

In rejecting the complaint , ORG held that , by virtue of the rule of exhaustion of remedies , it was for the complainant , prior to claiming protection from ORG , first to seek it from a higher level of the PPS by means of a repeated petition under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG .

CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE ( in case no . III . ÚS PERSON ) ORG declared inadmissible a complaint under LAW in which an individual had contested a decision of the ORG quashing a previous decision of an investigator to restore to the applicant cash and objects retained in the context of criminal proceedings against him .

In rejecting the complaint , ORG held that , by virtue of the rule of exhaustion of remedies , it was for the complainant , prior to claiming protection from ORG , first to seek it from a higher level of the PPS by means of a petition under LAW of LAW , irrespective of the fact that the decision was not subject to appeal under the ORG .

CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE ( in case no . III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ORG declared inadmissible a complaint under LAW , in which an individual had contested a decision by the ORG to reject an interlocutory appeal by the complainant against a decision of a lower level of the ORG to discontinue proceedings in the complainant ’s criminal complaint concerning an alleged violation of the privacy of a home . In that case , the interlocutory appeal had been rejected because , being in the procedural position of a victim , the complainant had no standing to appeal .

In rejecting the complaint , ORG held that , by virtue of the rule of exhaustion of remedies , it was for the complainant , prior to claiming protection from ORG , first to seek a review of the decision at the highest level of the PPS , that is to say ORG , under sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL of LAW .
At the same time , ORG observed that no grounds had been established for exempting the complainant from the obligation to use that remedy .

CARDINAL . The principles stemming from ORG decisions mentioned above were applied mutatis mutandis in ORG subsequent decisions of CARDINAL DATE ( in case no . IV . ÚS CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL DATE ( in case no . IV . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE ( in case no . II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , ORG declared inadmissible a complaint under LAW of DATE , in which a group of individuals had contested the outcome of the proceedings concerning their criminal complaint of an alleged abuse of official authority in connection with the termination of their service in the police .
ORG observed that the ORG criminal complaint had been rejected on DATE and that their interlocutory appeal to the ORG had been dismissed on CARDINAL DATE .
ORG found that , as the constitutional complaint had been lodged on DATE , it had clearly been lodged outside the statutory DATE time - limit for lodging such a complaint .

ORG held that the position had not been altered by the subsequent decisions at a higher level of the ORG to dismiss the ORG petition and repeated petition for reexamination of the lawfulness of the decision of DATE .

In reaching that conclusion , ORG observed that the ORG petition and repeated petition had been aimed at having a complaint in the interest of law ( sťažnosť pre porušenie zákona ) lodged by ORG on their behalf , which was however an extraordinary remedy , and a negative decision : accordingly it did not restart the running of the DATE time - limit .
CARDINAL . The offence of violence against a group of citizens and against an individual is defined in LAW , the relevant part of which reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . He who threatens a group of citizens with killing , causing bodily harm or causing damage on a large scale ( škoda veľkého rozsahu ) shall be punished by imprisonment for DATE .

CARDINAL . He who perpetrates violence against a group of citizens or an individual or threatens them with death , causing bodily harm or causing damage on a large scale on account of political belief , nationality , race , affiliation to an ethnic group , religion or because they are without religion , shall be punished by imprisonment for DATE . ”
CARDINAL . The offence of causing bodily harm is defined in Article CARDINAL , the relevant part of which provides that :
“ CARDINAL . He who intentionally causes bodily harm to another ’s health shall be punished by imprisonment for DATE or by a financial penalty . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL defines the offence of violating the privacy of a home , its relevant part reading as follows :
“ CARDINAL . He who enters a house or a flat of another without authority to do so or remains there unauthorised shall be punished by imprisonment for DATE or by a financial penalty ...

CARDINAL . NORP The perpetrator who , in committing the act referred to in LAW , applies violence or a threat of immediate violence and commits such an act with a weapon or with CARDINAL others shall be punished by imprisonment for DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . The offence of criminal damage is defined in Article CARDINAL , the relevant part of which provides that :

“ CARDINAL . He who destroys , damages or makes unusable something belonging to someone else and thereby causes a non - negligible damage ( škoda nie nepatrná ) to someone else ’s property shall be punished by imprisonment for DATE or interdiction of an activity or a financial penalty or forfeiture of an item of property . ”
CARDINAL . The communication was considered by ORG in an Opinion adopted at its meeting on DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP The case concerned difficulties that the petitioner and several other families , being of GPE ethnic origin , had been experiencing with settling down and establishing a home and , in particular , CARDINAL municipal resolutions forbidding the families in question from settling in the villages concerned and threatening them with expulsion .
The petitioner unsuccessfully complained about the municipal resolutions before ORG and a criminal investigation into the matter was suspended , by a decision of the PPS .

CARDINAL . In defending the case , the ORG party concerned argued , inter alia , that the petitioner had the opportunity to contest the decision to suspend the investigation under LAW of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and to assert her rights by way of an action for protection of her personal integrity under LAW seq . of LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG ) .
CARDINAL . The ORG , however , “ did not share the ORG party ’s view that domestic remedies had not been exhausted and considered that neither a new petition to ORG nor a civil action would be
CARDINAL . The communication was considered by ORG in an Opinion adopted at its meeting on DATE .

CARDINAL . The case concerned a NORP national , who had been refused service in a restaurant and was told to leave on account of his GPE ethnic origin , and an alleged failure by ORG to sanction or remedy this treatment . Following investigation upon the petitioner ’s criminal complaint in that respect , the police found that there was no evidence that any criminal offence had been committed . Upon the petitioner ’s appeal to the GPE , the decision was upheld .

CARDINAL . NORP In defending the case , the State party concerned argued , inter alia , that the petitioner had the opportunity to seek a review of the lawfulness of the position taken by the public prosecution service at a higher level in that body under LAW of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and of asserting his rights by way of an action for protection of his personal integrity under LAW seq . of LAW ( see CARDINAL of the ORG ) .

CARDINAL . NORP In response , the ORG observed that LAW ( a ) of LAW on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination provides that ORG is not to consider any communication unless it has ascertained that all available domestic remedies have been exhausted and that it has held in its previous jurisprudence that a petitioner is only required to exhaust remedies that are effective in the circumstances of the particular case ( see paragraph CARDINAL of the Opinion ) .

CARDINAL . Furthermore , the ORG noted that “ the decision of the [ PPS ] was a final decision as far as the criminal procedure was concerned . ORG [ had ] failed to demonstrate that a petition for review , which would be a remedy against the legality of the decision , could in the present case [ have ] [ led ] to a new examination of the complaint ” . Furthermore , the ORG found that “ the facts of the claim were of such a nature that only criminal remedies could constitute an adequate avenue of redress . The objectives pursued through a criminal investigation could not be achieved by means of civil or administrative remedies of the kind proposed by the ORG party ” . Therefore , the ORG found that “ no other effective remedies were available to the petitioner ” ( see paragraph CARDINAL of the Opinion ) .

CARDINAL . The communication was considered by ORG at its meeting on DATE . Among the views it adopted , in the relevant part of their paragraph CARDINAL , dealing with the requirement of exhaustion of domestic remedies , the ORG :

“ considered that , even if these attempts to engage available domestic remedies may not have complied with procedural formalities prescribed by law , they left no doubt as to [ the alleged victim ’s ] wish to have the allegations investigated . ORG concluded that , in the circumstances , it was not barred from considering the communication . ”
